notesStmt.note: The words "madd couple .. Damoiselle." are bracketed together on title page.
The portrait is signed: T. Cross sculpsit.
Printer's name from the Pforzheimer Catalogue. "The copy was divided between two compositors. One set-up through sheet S; the other, the remainder"--Pforzheimer Catalogue.
Signatures: pi1 A (-A6-8) B-S; A-F G⁴; A⁴ B-F G1-3 (=A6-8).

"The novella" and "The court begger" each have separate dated title page; register is continuous. "The city wit" (Wing B4866) and "The damoiselle" (Wing B4868) each have separate register and dated title page with "printed by T.R." in imprint. There is no indication that the latter two plays were ever issued separately, though they are sometimes found so (Greg).
"The Novella" identified on UMI microfilm (Early English Books 1641-17700) reel 1773 as wing B4880.
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library and the Harvard University Library.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. Digital page images are linked to the text file.

div.p: Acted at the Cock-pit, by his MAJESTIES Servants, Anno 1632.
Printed for RICHARD MARRIOT, and THO. DRING, and are to be ſold at their Shops in Fleet-ſtreet, 1653.

list.item: SIR Andrew Mendicant, an old Knight, turnd a pro|jector.
Mr. Swaynwit, a blunt Countrey Gentleman.
Mr. Citwit, a Citizens Son that ſuppoſes himſelfe a wi●.
Mr. Daynty, a ſuppoſed Pictured rawer, but a Pick-pocket.
Sir Raphael, an old Knight that talkes much and would be thought wiſe.
Sir Ferdinand, a Knight diſtracted for love of the Lady Strangelove.
Lady Strangelove, a humerous widow, that loved to be courted.

lg.l: WEe've cauſe to fear yours, or the Poets frowne
For of late day's (he know's not (how) y'are grown,
Deeply in love with a new ſtrayne of wit
Which he condemns, at leaſt diſliketh it,
And ſolemnely proteſts you are to blame
If at his hands you doe expect the ſame;
Hee'l tread his uſuall way, no gaudy Sceane
Shall give inſtructions, what his plot doth meane;
No handſome Love toy ſhall your time beguile
Forcing your pitty to a ſigh or ſmile.
But a ſlight piece of mirth, yet ſuch were writ
By our great Maſters of the Stage and Wit,
Whom you approv'd: let not your ſuffrage then
Condemne't in him, and prayſe't in other men.
Troth Gentlemen let me adviſe yee, ſpare
To vex the Poet full of age and care,
How he might ſtrive to pleaſe yee, and beguile
His humerous expectation with a ſmile,
As if you would be ſatisfy'd, although
His Comedy containes no antique ſhow.
Yet you to him your favour may expreſſe
As well as unto thoſe whoſe forwardneſſe
Make's them your Creatures thought, who in a way
To purchace fame give money with their Play,
Yet you ſometimes pay deare for't, ſince they write
Leſſe for your pleaſure than their own delight.
Which if our Poet fayle in, may he be
A Sceane of Mirth in their next Comedye.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: YO' have given him then his anſwer?

lg.l: Forc'd by you,
Heaven knowes with my much ſorrow. Such a Lover
So in all points deſerving of true worth,
And beſt indowments to make up a Man
That I ſhall never ſee—your pardon ſir,
Though you pulld back, by violence, my hand,
In which my heart was freely given to him,
It is not in your power or ſtrength of art
To beat a ſigh back, or reſtraine a teare
Which I muſt offer to his memory.
Such ſtormes ſoone waſt themſelves in abſent Lovers
When light of Reaſon, and good Counſell ſhall
Breake forth and ſhine upon 'em: and for your part
Daughter, I know it ſhall. And, preſently,
I thus begin to diſſipate your errors,
You love this Frederick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love knows I do.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You ſay he is deſerving in all points.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My love emboldens me to tell you he is.

lg.l: Chariſſa, take me with you. Is he not
Deficient in that onely abſolute point
That muſt maintaine a Lady, an eſtate?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love weighes not that.

lg.l: What can he ſhew you more
To take you with, then a wild head of hayre;
A very Limebuſh to catch Lady-birds?
A Tiſſue Doublet; and a Riband ſhop
Hung in his Hatbands, might ſet up a Pedler?
Can this maintaine a Lady?
You but looke
Upon his outſide ſir.
I truſt you have not
Bin over inwardly acquainted with him.
Sir, he has Valour, Wit, and Honour, you well know
Hee's of a noble Family extracted.
What's that a yeare? thoſe parts may be acquir'd
In winning of a ſtrumpet. But what Joincture
Can he propound to you? or, (in caſe he dyes,
Your Dowry being ſpent) what perſonall Eſtate
Iſt like hee'l leave you, but his Powder glaſſe,
His Combè and Beard-bruſh, and perhaps a Trunkfull
Of Elegies, Raptures, Madrigalls and Sonnets?
No let him goe; diſcard him: and embrace
The hopes that I have for thee in the hopefull,
Exquiſite Cavalier, Courtier and Souldier,
Scholler, (and what not!) brave Sir Ferdinando:
There's a Man riſing in the favour Royall,
And may in thee Chariſſa, make me happy.
Sir you have given me liberty of ſpeech;
And may be pleas'd to let me tell you now,
You aime at your own fortune, not at mine.
I ſeeke no fortune, but for thy advancement:
All that I ſhall call mine muſt be thine owne.
I would be playner yet; beſeeching you
I be not thought too loſe in my obedience.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Speake freely Girle.

lg.l: Your ayme has bin to raiſe
You ſtate by Court-ſuits, begging as ſome call it,
And for that end you left your Countrey life,
And Lands too ever ſince my Mother dy'd,
Who while ſhee liv'd with beſt of womans judgement
Which held you from that courſe of ſelling faire
Poſſeſſions to enable you with money
To purchace wit at Court. You pardon me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: On, on.

lg.l: And for th' Exchange of a faire Manſion-houſe
Large fruitfull Fields, rich Medowes and ſweet paſtures
Well cropt with corne and ſtockd as well with Cattell,
A parke well ſtor'd with Deere too, and Fiſhponds in't,
And all this for a lodging in the Strand now—
But doe I not offend?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, no, on ſtill.

lg.l: Your own fed Beefes and Muttons, Fowle and Poultry
Loaded your long boords then; and you had then
Neighbours could boaſt your hoſpitality,
And poore, that for the remnants prayd for you,
Now all concludes upon a two-diſhd table.
And whereas then you had a numerous Family
Of Servants and Attendants, out of which
For profit or for pleaſure you could call
Your Bayliffe, Groom, your Falconer, or your Huntſman,
Now ſir, a Varlet Coachman, and Footboy
Are all your Retinue; and for the Hounds
You kept, that made you ſport and Muſick, now
None but your project Beagles, that ſmell out
Where ſuch a forfeiture is to be begg'd;
Where one would purchaſe a Reprieve, another
A Pardon or a leaſe of Life Rope-free
For ready money: Then where Goods or Lands
Are found of men that make away themſelfes,
And ſo of fooles and madmen; All to ſet
Your trade of Begging up▪ and ſtill you beg:
But your own want of favour holds you back
From reaching any profit by't, becauſe
You beg by Mediators tongues, which you
Call Favorites, who reape the crop of all,
And leave you but the Gleanings; ſome ſmall pittance
To keepe alive the itch of begging in you—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Shee ſpeakes home and within me, to the purpoſe.

lg.l: Still waſting your own fortunes; till at laſt
You have no hopefull project life to thrive by
But to put me upon this ſuppos'd favorite
To beg for you when it is doubtfull yet
Whether hee'l take me with the Dowry, which
Mine Unkle left me, though you adde your projects.
The noble Gallant loves thee, Girle, and holds
Thy Perſon and thy vertues Dowry enough,
He is a wanton Lover, full of change,
And at this inſtant ſingularly devoted
Unto that humorous Lady, the young Widow.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: The Lady Strange love?

lg.l: Shee is ambitious
To draw all mens affections to her ſervice,
And then abuſes all by ſcornes or ſlightings,
And this (they ſay) has made him almoſt mad.
He mad! believe it not: his reaſon is
Married to him better then ſo. How now!
Ha' you ſeene the noble Knight from me?
How did he entertaine my Meſſage? ha!
Why ſpeakſt thou not? what anſwer has he ſent?
Hee's not Sir to be ſpoken with or ſeene
To any purpoſe, but by his Phiſitians.
So ſodainly and dangerouſly ſick,
Where are my hopes?
I cannot ſay how ſick
He is; nor can himſelfe give any account
Of his condition: for he is mad ſir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How! mad?

lg.l: Starke ſtaring mad; as mad
As you can thinke a Courtier muſt be
That is more mad then all the reſt.
If this be true I ſinke, what is ſuppos'd
The cauſe?
That ſir has puzzell'd all the Doctors
In weighing all his ſeverall wild affections;
One findes he was ambitious of Court favour,
And gueſſes he was croſſ'd in ſome great ſuite;
Another takes him as he was a Souldier,
And loſing coſt and travaile in the warre
Muſt loſe his wits for that. A third collects
He was a Poet that drunk too deepe of Helicon,
And turnd his braine in clyming of Parnaſſus:
A fourth conſidering that he was a Gamſter
Long and much favourd, and uprais'd by fortune
To mountaynous heapes of Gold, conjectures, that
Some late unlucky hand or chance at play
Hath with his money ſwept his wit away.
Fy, theſe can be no cauſes to remove,
Or ſhake his ſettled judgement or his temper.
Then ſir a fift and youngſt head among
The learned men (what call you him for a Doctor?
Hay that affects gay clothes and Flanders Laces,
That trim effeminate Gentleman) he
Has known this noble patient to have beene
An extreame Amoriſt, deſperatly devoted
Unto the ſervice of ſome threeſcore Ladies,
And honord every one the moſt in coſtly preſents,
Banquets and Verſes; and thinks the diſdaine
Of one or all of them has turnd his braine.
I told you ſir, the cauſe before; and nam'd
That humorous Lady for it, whom in heart
I can no leſſe then thanke.
Goe, get you up.
And ſtirre not from my Chamber on my bleſſing
Till my returne, nor admit any one
Unto a conference with you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I obey you.

lg.l: Some of your project ſearchers wait without ſir,
Loden it ſeemes with new intelligences.
They may come in: but as I feare they bring
Me little comfort, I am ſure I ſhall
Afford them none. Now ſirs, your buſineſſe?
We wait upon your honour my good Lord
To crave the knowledge of what good ſucceſſe
Your honor finds in our late ſuits my Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why honor? why my Lord?

sp.speaker: 2. Pro.
sp.p: We ſtile you now.

sp.speaker: 3. Pro.
sp.p: As all muſt doe hereafter.

lg.l: Yes, and that
In a ſhort ſpace of time, the world holds no
Proportion elſe, nor ſhall it more be ſayd
That money can buy Land; or great Eſtates
In Lands and Mannor-houſes be call'd Lordſhips.

sp.p: Or wealth joynd with deſert attaine to honor.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: So now the Game's afoot. They hunt in full cry.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: My Lord 'tis moſt apparant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How you torture me!

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Wee'l mak't appeare moſt plainly on our lives.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: And credits too.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Their Lives and credits, ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: That in the ſpace of one whole year our projects
Shall bring in fifty thouſand pounds to us,
And hundred thouſand to your ſelfe; and to
The Coffers Royall for full ſeaven years ſpace
64 Thouſand 783 l. 7 s. 9 d ob. q. per annum,
Tis here already caſt. Which to make good
Wee'l venture Lives and Goods.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Our Wives and Children.

div.stage: Mend. takes the ſcroll and peruſes it.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: We can ingage no more.

lg.l: A wondrous ſtrange ingagement
Your lives and goods; your wives & children gentlemen!
That's too deep ſet, and queſtions the Kings Mercy:
Me thinks it were enough, for non-performance
You would ſubmit your bodies to perpetuall
Impriſonment at the Kings charge; and leave
Your wives and children to their ſeverall Pariſhes
You are ſtill faithleſſe ſir, in all projects.
But when you ſhall perceive the wealthy ſonnes
Dayly brought in, and be, continually,
Troubled with the Receipts (if you may be truſted
That have ſo little faith) when you ſhall ſoyle
And gall your fingers ends with telling money,
Yet find the lickings of 'em ſweet, you'l then
Sing other Notes.
Meane time entreat my Lord
To put you to ſome Tellers Clearke to teach you
Ambo-dexterity in telling money.
Do you hear ſir? Can you give me two ſixpences
For a ſhilling—or any ſingle money?
Cry mercy, you weare none in ready coine,
But all in Bullion lockt up in your brave-cheſts,
And there you have the treaſure of the Indies;
Of deeper value, could it be digg'd out,
Then all the Hollanders have waited for
Theſe 7 yeares out of the Spaniſh plate fleets.
But put mine eye out (now I dare you to't)
With any ſingle peece of ready money.
My Lord your man abuſes us here ſtrangely
With his old misbeliefe. But ſtill we doubt not
Your honourable good opinion of us.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: You have pervs'd this weighty paper here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It weighes not all twelve graines.

lg.l: No more?
Nay the whole platforme of a ſtately City,
Or a deſigne to conquer a whole Nation,
But doe you note the grounds, the Rules and Reaſons,
Firſt for the eaſineſſe of the ſeverall grants.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Next for performance of our undertakings.

lg.l: And then the certainty o' th' propounded profit●
Both to the King and us.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: Without all grievance unto the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: That's no little marvaile.

lg.l: Take 'em into particulars my Lord,
Firſt this for Perrukes. The Monopoly
Of making all the Perrukes male and female,
Through Court and Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: There's a capitall project.

lg.l: Note the neceſſity, that they be well made
Of no diſeas'd or infectious ſtuffe, of dead or living,
No verminous or ſluttiſh locks or combings,
But harmleſſe and ſound haire, of innocent,
And wholeſome people.
They muſt then reape none
From Gallowſes, nor Hoſpitalls; from whence
They have had great ſupplies.
You have in that
Said very well; For here's a Reformation
Of that abuſe intended in theſe words
Innocent and wholſome.
How if a man or woman ſhall deſire
To weare a friends hayre ſo departed; as
You his; or your wife yours; may't not be had?
Or if your friend or Miſtris dye ſo, you
Procure the haire and bring it from the Gallows
To th' office, and it may be done accordingly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You have in that ſaid very well Sir too.

lg.l: Now out of this proviſion, what an infinite
Profit will riſe i' th' generall uſe of 'em,
And multiplicity that will be worne
By people of all ſorts▪ degrees and ages:
The old to hide their naturall baldneſſe, and
The young and middle-ag'd their artificiall
Or accidentall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: By the pox or ſo.

lg.l: They ſhall be brought into that reputation
That none ſhall be eſteem'd ſo ſound or wiſe
As publique wearers of them: which to effectuate
Tis requiſite that you obtaine a Mandat
Unto all Courtiers, that would be thought wiſe
To weare falſe hayre: becauſe clownes have been noted
To talke like fooles or mad men in their own.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No more of that.

lg.l: What ſay to this my Lord,
Touching new faſhions of apparrell; ſutes,
Hats, Boots, Swords, Belts, Ribands, &c.
For every wearer of his firſt o'th' faſhion
To pay a groat to th' King; and every Tradeſman
Two pence on every ſeverall piece he ſells
Of any ſuch new faſhion the firſt yeare?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And what may this pride money amount unto Per annum, can you gueſſe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not meddle in it.
No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, nor your Perrukes neither.
What ſay to this my Lord of the Balconyes?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor that.
This then for ſucking out of cornes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away with it.

lg.l: This then: that on the birth of every Girle
The Father pay a groat; to hearten men
To live ſoberly and get Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away.

lg.l: This makes amends for all then. A new project
For buylding a new Theatre or Play-houſe
Upon the Thames on Barges or flat boats
To helpe the watermen out of the loſſe
They've ſuffer'd by Sedans; under which project
The ſubject groanes, when for the eaſe of one
Two abler men muſt ſuffer; and not the price,
Or pride of Horſe-fleſh or Coach-hire abated.
This ſhall bring flouds of gaine to th' watermen
Of which they'l give a fourth of every fare
They ſhall boord at the floating Theatre,
Or ſet aſhore from thence, the Poets and Actors
Halfe of their firſt yeares profits.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fy away.

lg.l: This is a weighty one: For maſſy ſummes
That may be freely given out of the City,
To have but this aſſurance, that hereafter
They may ingroſſe the getting of their own
Children: by order tane that Cavaliers,
And Courtiers may no more invade,
Or mix with Tradeſmens wives: whereby tis thought
So many City Prodigalls have been gotten;
Onely the thrifty countrey Gentlemen
To be excepted: for by them 'tis gueſt
So many Citizens grow landed men.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Were not they gotten by Projectors think you?
My Lord your ſervant jeeres us.

lg.l: To deale plainely
I doe allow't in him—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Heaven has heard my prayers.

lg.l: And will heare him or any man oppoſe
All that is put to me by way of project
To put me by all further hopes in 'em:
For (with hearts griefe I ſpeake it) he by whom
I onely hop'd to climbe (alas) is fallen.

sp.p: What out of favour?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, out of his Reaſon.
The noble Cavalier ſir Ferdinando.

lg.l: That late ſtood candidate for the favour royall,
Is he now fallen beſides himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Even he.

lg.l: What have you then to doe my Lord
In lieu of all your ſervice but beg him?
His greater and his nearer friends at Court
Will prevent me.

sp.p: They ſhall not, never feare it.

lg.l: Come we will make quick worke of this.
My Lord you ſhall disburſe but twenty pieces.
Among us three. 3. And we will inſtantly
Finde his eſtate. 1. And lay you down a way
So plaine that you ſhall ſay All's yours,
Before you ſtir a foot.
But when he has travell'd
Till he has tir'd himſelfe, he ſhall returne,
And ſay All's loſt, iſt not ſo Gentlemen?
I will not part with any money ſirs.
Truſt me you doe not well to put my Lord
Off o' his benefit, by diſheartning him
In this ſmall venture. Will you then be pleas'd
To give us but ten pieces.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a penny.

lg.l: Five you ſhall my Lord,
And ſtand no longer thus in your own light.

sp.p: Or but a piece a Man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a denier.
A dinner then my Lord, but of one piece.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My anſwers cannot pleaſe you. Anſwer 'em you.

lg.l: I wonder how you having ſtretch'd your throats
With the loud ſounds of thouſands, hundred thouſands
Can, after all, ſo faintly whiſper forth
One piece; and that as much in vaine, as all
The maſſy ſummes: for all but brings you nothing,
It ſhewes you Gentlemen of reſolute patience;
And would take thankfully I warrant you
An od halfe crowne amongſt you: and what ſay you
To every man a kick on the condition?
What ſay you to one with tother?
This abuſe
Shall loſe your Maſter a hundred thouſand pound.
Goe coine your bullion braines into the money
And come againe. My maſter was
Your Lord even now, as he was Lord of Beggers.

sp.p: I hope to live to ſee him beg of us.

lg.l: Out hundreds, thouſands, ten thouſands, hundred, thouſands, Millions, ten Millions, Millions upon Millions
Away, i'le ſtamp your buttocks into coyne elſe. Ex. Pro|jectors.
The Devill ride that hind moſt of 'em, for
A raw bon'd Jade: Sfoot he has lam'd my toes.
I am glad I am ſo rid of' em, and now
As th'art my Servant and my loving Kinſeman—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: To follow you in all things but in Projects.

lg.l: Looke to my Houſe and Daughter, that ſhe ſtart not;
Nor any entrance be allowd to Fredrick
To re-intangle her in his Love. I know
Thy vertue and thy valour can make good
My truſt impos'd in thee.
You need not feare ſir
But, good ſir, no more projects.
I have but one,
On which I'le ſet my reſt. Thoult ſay tis good.
Except it be the begging of this Madman
It can be nothing.
Tis the very ſame:
By which I will advance my houſe and name.
The Beggers beſt is that he feeles no ſhame:
Sprecious what meane you? Ha'you forgot ſo ſoone
Your Fathers ſtrict command, and he ſcarce gone yet?
Alas hee'l then meet Fredrick and divert him,
I ſaw him at the window making this way.
He gets no entrance to you. I muſt obay
A maſter though you can neglect a father.
Be not ſo cruell. Thou mayſt live to love,
And need the pitty of a friend.
I pitty you,
And will do no more then you know how to aske
For your own good. I underſtand your cauſe
And can relieve you if you'l yeild to councell.
You are my Kinſman; and have bin my friend,
Though you obſerve my father who, I feare,
Has not a fathers love towards me.
His love is great and certaine,
And all his travell is for your advancement:
But he goes blindfold on unproſperous wayes
Led by credulity. Projects! pox o' projects
The patron of his projects is (it ſeemes)
Pepper'd with madneſſe. Tis but Juſtice on him,
And now i'le give you a ſecret if you'l promiſe
To be ruld by me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: You ſhall rule me coſen.

lg.l: This Ferdinand, your fathers great Court-godling
Nere ſought you for a wife; but to have whor'd you:
(That is the Engliſh on't) and to appeare
A right great man in th'act, he would ha' made
By hopes and promiſes your credulous Father
The inſtrument of your proſtitution:
Which to effect, (though ſtill he undertook
His hopefull projects) cunning Lawyer-like
He croſt or loſt him ſtill in all, on purpoſe
That poverty at length might urge him to
Give you to his diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This was my feare.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Away: ſome body comes.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tis Fredrick. I muſt ſee him.

lg.l: You'l never ſee him more then. Go to your cham|ber.
A little patience and he ſhall be yours.
So dos a heart conſume in lingring fire,
When cooling hopes are caſt on hot deſire.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Poore heart I pitty her, and will labour for her.

lg.l: O Gabriel! I am happy in finding thee,
Thy maſter abſent, whom I ſaw, in haſt
Now paſſing towards the Court. Where's my Chariſſa?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You may not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May not ſee her ſir?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: May not! nay muſt not: ſhall not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Y'are very plaine with me.

lg.l: Her owne command
Warrants me ſpeake it ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A villaine ſpeakes it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I have a ſword ſpeakes other language for me.

lg.l: Can ſhe whoſe thoughts are truth, and written here,
Here in this breaſt, giving me ample welcome,
Give thee a countermand to bar me from it?
Wouldſt thou make her a double hearted monſter?
Or like another woman?
Repent the● of thy treſpaſſe yet and live.
Sir, if you thinke to fight, talke not too much;
Or, if you needs muſt talke, then heare as well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou ſay?

lg.l: Sir, I have more to ſay
Then fits this place, ſince you are apt to quarrell;
And this no ground to buſtle on: nor indeed
Where I dare for my honeſty and truſt
Allow you longer ſtay. If therefore you
Will walke, I'le wait upon you; and direct you
In a more ready way to finde Chariſſa.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is ſhee not here i'th' houſe?

lg.l: O ſir, a man
May come within his arme-reach of his money
In the Exchequer: but he muſt walke about
To finde due order e're he draw it out.
The fellow's honeſt, valiant, and diſcreet,
Full man, in whom thoſe three additions meet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Sir, dare you truſt me?

lg.l: Yes I dare; and why?
Becauſe if thou dar'ſt fight, thou dar'ſt not lie.
HEre in this gallery Gentlemen you may▪ at your pleaſure,
Untill my Lady comes, walk or ſit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Or lie down if you pleaſe.

lg.l: If you ſo, wrong not my Ladies Couch with your
Spurres I pray▪ take heed you leave not a Rowell there.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: If one ſhould, your Lady has no Lord to call her honour to queſtion, whoſe Knight-hood it belong'd unto.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You have a good countrey wit ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My name is Swayne-wit; and for all you twit me with the Countrey, I am a Gentleman tho'.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I honour you the more ſir, for I am a Countrey Maide my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sw.

lg.l: Thou art a baggage, and a bold one, I am deceiv'd elſe.
I would be further acquainted with you tho'. Kiſſe long.
Have you done now? You will have time enough for
Further and better acquaintance.

sp.p: Thou art a Jackanapes of the baſeſt tricks that ever I ſaw, for a halfe-penny. Shee's your choyce, is ſhee? Could not you let be tho'? I ha' bin acquainted with thee but two dayes, and forgi'me for ſwearing, I ha' found thee beating ripe a skore o' times at leaſt. Take heede I be|gin not now, and hand ſell your Ladies houſe, that is ſo much talkt on, and your Gentlewomans preſence here with a fiſt about your eares.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Not for a thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: That's a great deale of money. I could find i'my heart to do't tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Slife we are all undone then.

lg.l: He ſets my teeth on edge to looke upon him:
He lookes ſo like a wilding crab, good neither for drink nor ſauce.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Why would you preſſe him then?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou haſt a verjuice wit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: For my poore ſake forbeare ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Let him ſtand further then, and looke o' to● ſide.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, this is no cauſe nor place to fight in, when—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What ſayes he?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nothing, you heare he whiſtles tother way.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tother way, what backwards?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: What new gueſt ha' you brought here Mr. Court|wit, for my Lady to laugh at?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: One for that purpoſe Phil, you ha' ſpoke the man, But what company has my Patroneſſe, that ſhee is yet buſy.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that! If ſhee be long buſy I will not ſtay, and ſhee were ten great Ladies, or one as big as twenty, for all ſhee is your Patroneſſe, muſt we wait out of our wits, becauſe Chalivere ran mad for her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Ha' you heard o' that ſir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My Cozen Court-wit's queſtion was who's with her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O ſweet Mr. Court-wit, when will you bring the fine civill Gentleman, that maintaines himſelfe ſo gal|lantly by picture drawing?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a new buſineſſe! Fare yee well, pray tell your Lady I came not from Penſans to grow here.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nay ſweet ſir ſtay, there is ſir with my Lady none but the grave and witty talking Knight. Some call him the metrapolitane wit of Court; he that loves Ladyes ſo|ciety ſo much, and yet has vow'd virginity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: As much as in man lies Phil; Hee is a perpetuall vowd batchellor indeed, and as conſtant to his vow as to his faſhion in apparrell, which is ever the ſame, ſir Raphael Winter-plum.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That old witherd piece. I know him.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wilt beare up again.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He has lick'd up a living with his tongue; makes all great tables his own; and eats for his talke: He may be converſant with women: for (they ſay) he guelt him|ſelfe
beyond Sea for ſpight one did him; and now preaches chaſtity to Ladies, and love to their husbands. Hee's a Lay-goſpeller among the married ſort, and an eſpeciall pedant to the youth o' Court.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fy, thou ſpeakſt too much.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There's another humor I could beat thee for with all my heart, thou wilt ſpeake outragiouſly of all men behinde their backs, and darſt not anſwer Ba—to the face of a ſheep, O I could pommell thee.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This is not yet a cauſe to fight for, when—

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: But will not that fine Gentleman Mr. Dainty come, Mr. Court-wit?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I expect him preſently.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I'le ſee if their conference be ended, or breake it if I can, and haſten my Lady to you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: This wench has a dainty wit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee may, living with the prime Lady-wit in towne.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But what Dainty is that ſhee talkes on ſo affecti|onately?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Troth a Gentleman that lives at a good rate; very civill in converſation, keepes good company; yet none of his acquaintance that I am acquainted with knowes his beginning, or his preſent meanes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I know no more but by his port, and faſhion, you ſaw him with me laſt night.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for ſwearing, Iſt he?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He was at the Play with us too, doe you not re|member that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, that I was at the Play, by ſure token and a ſad one.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le ſhew you ſomewhat of him. A Gentleman borne did you aske?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Now he beares up againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hee cannot be a Gentleman by birth or place. A fine-handed, and a fine headed fellow he is; and pre|tends great skill and practice too in Picture-drawing, Watch-making, and ſuch like finger-workes; which he ſayes he uſes as a Gentlemans exerciſe, not as a trade to live upon; when either he does live on't; or elſe hee has ſome more ſecret way, as perhaps pimping or purſing for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There he is again! Art thou bound in conſcience to wrong all men in their abſence, till I beate thee into better manners?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I prithee hold.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yet ſtill the cauſe is inſufficient, when—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Here comes the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Is hee come? Noble Mr. Dainty—The wel|comſt in the World. I proteſt I ſuffer'd by your abſence.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You do me too much honour Mr. Cit-wit.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Oh ſir, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Ha, ha. Forgi' me for ſwearing, what a Spaniell's this?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are well found, I was a little ſtayd by the way upon receipt of monies. Ha' you ſeene the Lady yet?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee's yet a little buſy. We ſhall all inſtantly take the opportunity together.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: But Gentlemen; you that have better knowledge of this Lady informe if you pleaſe, why are we ſummond hither?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakſt as if thou hadſt guilt upon thee; fear nothing man.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
I that's the thing that I would underſtand too. And why me of any man? They ſay indeed ſhee is a hu|morous Lady, and loves to buſy her ſelfe. But what are we to her? are there not greater men, and Lords enough
for her to foole away the time with, but we muſt danc● attendance on her humors?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I proteſt Mr. Swayn-wit, I admire your inge|nuity.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You will be medling ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Tis to your queſtion ſir, which I will anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I there's another of your cockſcombly tricks, to anſwer any queſtion, that's ask'd another man, out with tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This Lady ſir, this humorous wity Lady is a wit|ſponge, that ſuckes up wit from ſome, and holds as her own, untill ſhee ſqueeze it out on others. Shee will make uſe of ours, or any courſer wits; and ſearch 'em out to ſift 'em. Shee will collect from market-folkes; and hold conferences with the poore Trades people that cry their wares about the ſtreets, Shee will rake wit out of a dunghill Ragwoman.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: So there he is againe! dareſt thou abuſe a noble Lady, in her owne houſe too? I dare not now but beat thee.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare good coſen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Still, ſtill, the cauſe is naught, when—

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Ods ſo the Ladies comming I think.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lady cannot yet be rid of the tedious talking Knight. But ſhee will caſt him preſently. He is now following her into this roome, pray paſſe into the next; my Ladies Muſick roome. There you ſhall find a collation of good Tobacco and Sack and one to attend you, you know the faſhions of the Houſe Mr. Court|wit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come away Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I could even love and looke upon that ſweete Mr. Dainty a whole houre methinks.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Goe your wayes down Mayd, and if any aske for Sir Raphael here, ſay that I hope hee will ha' done anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You would be rid of me: but pardon me Madam, I muſt hold your glaſſe to you.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: That's a poore Chamber-mayds office; and ill becomes your gravity Sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'le open then the booke to you of your errors.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now you ſpeake ſcholler-like, and your ſelfe: But have we ſpent all this while in by, and idle talke, and have that volume to be open'd yet? Pray read mee for the firſt Leſſon for this Mornings Exerciſe, and my Edification, the laſt Chapter of my book of errors as you call it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are a mocker of inſtruction, and good counſell.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Begins it ſo? whom is that ſpoken to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I ſpeak to onely you; to conjure (if I can) that ſpirit of ſcorne out of you; which you have taken in, and long affected for a humor, your ſingular own humor, till it is grown ſo familiar, ſo inherent in you, that you have wonne the title of the humorous Lady by't; and drawn a ſcorne upon your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Why then all's paid, and wellcome good Sir Raphael.

lg.l: I am not gone ſo; nor is all ſo payd:
For there's a greater reckoning yet of Raylings,
Reviling, Curſes by the many that
Y'have ſcornd and ſlighted, ſhot at you in hot vollies.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: They hit me not. I am ſure I do not feele 'em.

lg.l: You may in time be ſenſible of their ſuffrings,
Whom you have violently, and willfully abus'd
With ſcorne and pride; if you call to mind
The cauſe, bred meerly out of humour; cauſe you would have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You come too neare mee ſir, cauſe I would have it ſo?

lg.l: Can it be otherwiſe? Has it not ever bin
Your practiſe, ſince your time of widow-hood
To catch all mens affections? Tis indeed
An honour to a Lady to have many ſuitors;
But to lay bait for 'em only to delude 'em—
Is impiouſly diſhonorable.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Have I done ſo?

lg.l: Yes, and have gloried in it for your humour
To lead men into brakes with fooliſh fire.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: If they will follow it, I cannot helpe it.

lg.l: You might though have prevented the miſhaps
Of many, by a faire and free reſiſtance
In the beginnings of their ſuits of Courtſhips,
And not to ſet your ſelfe at gaze to draw them on,
And then allure them with aſſured hopes
Of love and favour till you have wound their follies
Into the reach of your diſdaine; and then
To torture 'em, or having ta ●e 'em captives
To ſlave and ſell 'em to the worlds deriſion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: O ſir Raphael—

lg.l: Shee feeles compunction!
I will purſue it to the quick.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: On good Sir Raphael.

lg.l: Conſider then good Madam, ſince I know,
And your own conſcience knowes, that you have made
A ſecret vow from your late husbands death
Never to marry, how better and more glorious
It would be for your honor to declare
Your conſtant purpoſe to a ſingle life,
Then to fall into the tranſgreſſion
Of robbing men ſo of their wits and reaſon,
And all by willfull humor: as this late
Unhappy accident of madneſſe in
The hopefull Knight Sir Ferdinando cryes
Lowdly to your diſgrace, and the worlds ſorrow.
Halfe the worlds ſorrow is mine own
For that ſad accident, I would I coold redeem't
With halfe my health or life. But let me tell you
(Now you have juſtly chidden me) that you
Have a fault too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What iſt in your conſtruction?

lg.l: As I conceal'd my vow of ſingle living,
And gave men leave to court me, by which meanes
I won them into hopes, and robd their wits,
You in declaring to the Court and City
Your vow of chaſtity and ſingle life,
Yet dayly, nightly, howerly frequenting
The company of Ladies, with your ſweet,
No leſſe then grave diſcourſe and converſation
Have rob'd (nay I may ſay deflowr'd) more Ladies
Of chaſt and honorable thoughts, then all
The cavalry of Court.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who I Madam!

lg.l: Even you ſir Raphael (if unchaſt deſires
Muſt be held ſinfull) I know ſome of them,
And one (I feare) too well, that have bin ſubject
Unto the breach of any vow for you,
Yet you to vow a ſingle and chaſt life;
And publiſh your intent!
Tis with intent,
And a religious purpoſe to decline,
And divert womans fond affections from me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: O, but forbidden things are womens longings! You have read, you have read (ſir Raphael) you have read.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And travell'd too: yet never could diſcover Such an example.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray ſit down by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good thoughts poſſeſſe you Madam. I muſt hence.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le not be tedious to you. One word I pray ſir?

lg.l: Vertue, be thou my armor. Briefly then
Let me intreat you Madam▪
Pray refuſe not
To ſit downe by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sanctity protect me.

lg.l: Sir, you are famous, and cry'd up by all
For your great wiſdome, Morall and Divine:
You are the Ipſe dixit of the Court
As I have heard you ſtil'd by men of learning.
The Court Philoſopher—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam to the point.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What is our ſtrength, and what is not our frailty?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Where is ſhee wandering now? Bee playner Madam.

lg.l: Doe not my bluſhes (which I hope you pardon)
Deliver you a meſſage from my heart?
Which I want words to ●●●●r? O theſe vowes!
Theſe raſh and ill-made vowes! dos not your judgement
Read ſomething on this face? pray look upon me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am no good interpreter of looks.

lg.l: I dare not ſpeake, till you have firſt remov'd
A weighty ſcruple, which doth much perplexe me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You muſt firſt ſpeake it Madam.

lg.l: Whether theſe vowes,
(I meane your own, and mine, for ſingle life)
May ſafely be diſpens'd with or abſolv'd,
And we become a lawfull paire in Marriage?
Pray ſir reſolve and bleſſe me in a Match.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam I'le pray for you.

lg.l: You will firſt kill me
With your diſdaine, and then you'l pray for me!
Is that your Charity?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I dare not heare you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Leave me not ſo.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who waits upon my Lady here?

lg.l: I had no other way to ſhift him, would he would make
An errand now to Rome to quit my ſcruple;
And rid the Court of an officious foole:
Women ſome times have ſent wiſe men to ſchoole.
Is the Knight gone?
And bleſſing of himſelfe,
As witch craft were i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But where's my favorite Court-wit, has he brought his countrey Kinſman and the reſt?

lg.l: They are all in your wit-office Madam (as you call the Roome)
Paſſing the time among the Pipes and Bottles,
And ſinging catches. Here you may here 'em Ma|dam.
Marry, this takes paſt▪ all ſir Raphaels Lectures,
Goe call 'em downe. Exit Phi.
This Madam troubles me, 'would he were right agen;
Or I quit of the ſcandall. Enter Court-Swain, and Cit-wit.
O Gentlemen! y'are welcome,
And chiefly you that are the onely ſtranger,
I ha' been ſo troubled with an overtalking ſi●, that he
Has wound me into melancholly—

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I wiſh you mirth Madam. I come not as one o' you-fooles to make you any though—Offer to go away.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Be not ſo briefe with mee, let mee intreat you though.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi'me for ſwearing doe you mock me tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Miſtake me not ſweet ſir—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
Sweet with a miſchiefe! How ſweet am I? I come
not as a ſuitor to your great Ladyſhip. I am a Gentleman of two hundred a yeare tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Not as a ſuitor to me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: No you are too great for me. Nor to your Mopſey without, though ſhee be ſnout-faire, and has ſome wit ſhee's too little for me, I underſtand degree and quality, reſpect and difference; and am ſcholler enough to know my unde and my quare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ga' me his true character. You are a com|pleat Gentleman ſir (if I miſtake not) the Kinſman of my favorite here, who has given me an ample relation of your worth and vertue.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Yes, Patroneſſe, 'tis he, who though not throughly vers'd, or converſant i'th' Court or City garbe, he under|ſtands both Men and Manners.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Prattle for your ſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But to the buſineſſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that I would faine know if it be any.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You have heard I doubt not of a diſaſtrous blot lately caſt upon my 〈…〉e, out of my owne free|neſſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Concerning the Mad-courtier Madam, when 'tis as likely, that his Taylor made him mad as you, for not hitting the faſhion right in his laſt rich ſuit. But tis moſt like he fell from a reaſonable man, by over-ſtudying him|ſelfe what Lord he ſhould be at the next creation, whe|ther of Gleek, or Cribbidge;
In and in, or Hazard.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Hearke how this ſhotten headed Cocks-combe prates! And how he, that can indure beating, dares ſpeak any thing, or abuſe all men! canſt not give the Lady leave to ſpeake tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
Since there is an aſperſion layd upon my freeneſſe in giving entertainment unto perſons of great and noble qua●ity, the world deeming it to be done by me meerly
for oſt●ntation, to cry my own humor up, by drawing them into Love-knots, and then to ſlight or ſcorne them. My reſolution is from henceforth, to exclude thoſe great reſorts, and friendly and freely be merry within our ſelfes. I have foure thouſand a yeare to ſpend; and will be huſwife good enough to keepe in compaſſe. I will not entertaine a ſervant, friend or gueſt above your rank or fortunes—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why—(forgi'me for ſwearing) what do you think of us?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I thinke you Gentlemen of worth and quality: and therefore welcome, I thinke you able to maintaine your ſelfes midle-ſis'd Gent.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am Midleſex indeed; borne i'th' City.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Give the Lady leave to ſpeake tho'.

lg.l: I'le give acceſſe to none, that the cenſorious world ſhall dare to judge a ſuitor to me,
Or to finde favour further then meat and wine.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, faith a little money to; and make's your Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray give the Lady leave to ſpeak though.

lg.l: Mauger the greatneſſe of my former viſitants
I give you my election for the chiefes
Of my familier ſociety.
I may perhaps call in, (at leaſt admit)
People of meaner garbe, without (I hope
Your grudge or envy. But they ſhall be men
Of Science, Art, and Action.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Of action Madam? who do you meane? the Players?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Why not? I love their quality and them, and mean to have the uſe of ſome of 'em ſhortly: Beſides Muſiti|ans (Poets in the firſt place) and Painters: In which laſt mention'd art I heare you are excellent, though all this while ſo ſilent.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I boaſt no skill or practiſe Madam: but I have drawne ſome pieces that have been worth my paines in my Rewards.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I muſt commend their ingenuity for whom you tooke thoſe paines. But (where I left) I muſt make uſe of wits, of arts, and actions.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here in your houſe Madam, I would be glad to ſee the Actors, but I ſaw 'em at their own too lately: for I loſt my purſe there, no matter let it go. There was 15. pound in't tho!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sprecious! How now! my Fob has been ●ubd to day of ſix pieces, and a dozen ſhillings at leaſt. No|thing but a bowd groat left as I hope for my Grannums bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sure you have been in ſome ill company.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pox of ill company I ſay. My watch is gone out of my Pocket too o'th right ſide.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You roſe o'the wrong ſide to day it ſeemes, were you in no crowd or quarrell?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I never was in a〈…〉 quarrell i'my life. I alwayes run from 'em.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I dare ſweare thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I onely ſtood to day at the Coranto-ſhop to read the laſt great news; and I was hoop'd in I remember by ſome that ſeem'd to wonder as much as I.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Then certainly there was a cut-purſe amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le go to honeſt Moll about it preſently.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But firſt ſtay and heare my Lady tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I Madam you were ſpeaking of the uſe you would make of Poet, Painter, Muſick, Actor and the like.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
True favorite for a Maſque that I intend to have ſhortly, you ſhall performe the poeticall part, your
ſervant Citwit the Muſicall. And by your skill and directi|ons the Painters office for the ſcenes. Dancers and ſpea|kers I have in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I muſt be ſomething too tho', muſt I not Ma|dam?

lg.l: Marry and thanke you too ſir. Enter Philomil.
Now your Newes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Mendicant deſires to ſee you Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ſhould have told him I would not be ſeene by him.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I told him you were buſy. But hee ſayes hee is to ſpeake with you upon a weighty buſineſſe from the Court.

lg.l: Tis the Court-begger. You know him favorite.
Goe not away, I'le bring him in amongſt you,
And (as you love me) put ſome ridiculous projects to him.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What's that ſir An●●●w Mendicant? doe you know him well?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Thou askeſt ſtill a queſtion like a guilty perſon, with a look reſembling fear upon thy face.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: My countenance is too blame then; not my con|ſcience.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le tell you what he is.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Still anſwering others queſtions?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He is a Knight that hanckers about the Court, ambitious to make himſelfe a Lord by begging. His braine is all Projects, and his ſoule nothing but Court-ſuits. He has begun more knaviſh ſuits at Court, then ever the Kings Taylor honeſtly finiſh'd, but never thriv'd by any: ſo that now hee's almoſt fallen from a Pallace B●gger to a ſpittle one. His buſineſſe to my Lady now can be no|thing but to borrow money to buy a paire of wheeles
to ſet ſome Project a going to Court for a Mo|nopoly.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wert in haſt e●ne now to looke after the money; but and thy Life lay on't thou muſt ſtay to abuſe a man ●ehinde his back, who is a noble Gentleman thou knowſt, and I have heard, yet (ſpeake in thy conſcience) wouldſt thou not be beaten now?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare, they come.

lg.l: Sir, ſince it is requeſted by thoſe great ones
Whoſe power cannot command me in this caſe
(For tis my charity and not my duty)
I am content that the mad Ferdinand
Shall ſo journe in my houſe for his recovery.
Tis thought you were the ground-work of his frenſy
The Doctors therefore mov'd their honours to it
For that your frequent preſence may be helpfull
Towards his care.
He ſhall have it th●●
Towards the expiation of the crime
They charge me with. But in caſe ſir Andrew
He ſhould be cur'd by this meanes, I ſhould then
Croſſe you in fortune and your future hopes
Of his eſtate; which you have beg'd you ſay
If he recover not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I muſt leave that to fortune Madam.

lg.l: Will you be pleas'd ſir to take notice of
Theſe Gentlemen my friends. They may be uſefull Salute
For they have all projective braines I tell you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray of what nature are your Projects Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sir my affection leanes much to Poetry, eſpecialy the Drammatick.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Writing of ſtrange Playes?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I am glad I ſpeake ſir, to your underſtanding.
And my project is that no Playes may be admitted to the Stage, but of their making who Profeſſe or indea|vour to live by the quality: That no Courtiers, Divines, Students at Law, Lawyers-clearks, Tradeſmen or Pren|tiſes be allow'd to write 'em, nor the Works of any lay-Poet whatſoever to be receav'd to the Stage, though freely given unto the Actors, nay though any ſuch Poet ſhould give a ſumme of money with his Play, as with an Apprentice, unleſſe the Author doe alſo become bound that it ſhall doe true and faithfull ſervice for a whole Terme.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Here's a trim buſineſſe towards, and as idle as the Players going to Law with their Poets.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I have another ſir, to procure a Patent for my ſelfe to have the onely priviledge to give inſtructions to all the actors in the City, (eſpecially the younger ſort) the better to enable them to ſpeake their parts emphatically and to the life.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You were beſt take heede in time then that you well preſerve your own voyce, for feare you doe a ſpoyle among 'em in teaching 'em to utter in unſavory tunes. Doe I come hither to be mock'd?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Will you heare mine though? I am a Countrey Gentleman, young, healthfull and luſty. I heare com|plaints of barrenneſſe in the City; and of men that can|not get their wives with child; Get me but a Patent for't I'le undertake by my ſelfe and deputies (provided that the woman be ſound and handſome) to make them mul|tiply, and upon reaſonable conditions: we will deale with the rich for money, and the poore for cha|rity.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is fooliſher then tother. Doe you abuſe me Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Is that a wiſe man's queſtion? you cannot tell th'o.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We have our projects too Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I would have yours firſt, you ſeeme a civill and ſubſtantiall Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: In more private if you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I like well his reſervedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir I am a Picture-drawer Limner, or Painter (if you pleaſe) and wou'd gladly purchaſe authority, by my ſelfe and deputies, for the painting of all the Kings, and Queenes-head ſignes for Tavernes, Innes, Ale houſes, and all Houſes and Shops of Trade throughout the King|dome upon this ground that they draw and hang up their t●yall Images for ſignes in ſo hideous manner that men bleſſe themſelves to ſee't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I marry this hangs upon ſome ground. But are you an exquiſite workeman in that art ſi●?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I am an Artiſt in that miſtery ſir, and have drawn ſome of his Majeſties Pictures (by coppy onely but) ſo to the life, that Gentlemen have kneel'd to '●m for ſuites, and knight-hoods.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Indeed ſir!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and great Lords I have pictur'd ſo power|fully, their own followers ſodainly ruſhing into the room have ſtarted back, and ſolemnly ſtood bare to 'em as they hung o'the walls.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I drew a ſterne Judge, and a civill Lawyer ſo to the life, that after their corps were in the Grave, a man durſt not looke upon their pictures without a bribe, or double fee in's hand.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I do admire you!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I ha' drawn Ladies too, with that alluring beau|ty, that men have lov'd their dead pictures, for their pain|ted lookes, more then their living perſons for all their vertues.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou boy! introth you abuſe me moſt merrily Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: An excellent fellow: I like him for that fancy more then all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray heare my project too ſir?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Yes good ſir Andrew, you ſhall not part ſo ab|ruptly.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Mine is a good common wealths buſineſſe, againſt the common Plague, that raignes i'th' City of Pick|pockets, and Cut-purſes▪ I my ſelfe ha' bin robb'd to day, and am going to a good member that deales in private for the recoveries of ſuch goods: One that ſhall under|take if you'l but get a Patent, for a Cutpurſe-hall, or Office, to helpe all men to their owne againe, allowing but the Tithes of their Loſſes, and freeing the offending parties.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fie, fie. Here's tithing indeed.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Provided that notice be brought to the Office within foure and twenty houres after any ſuch loſſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Enough, enough.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Wee may by the ſame courſe ſecure the Coun|ties too, and make the hangman hang himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let every man be wiſe enough to looke to his purſe, and there will be no Cut-purſes, nor need of your patent.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: As wiſe a man as you may loſe his purſe tho', as I ha' done my ſelfe in a crow'd.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He puts me in mind of a crowd I was in once to day of company I lik'd not—ha—. For hea|ven 'tis gone: And I dare not diſcover it for being laught at.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: It ſeemes none of your Projects will paſſe with you ſir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come ſir, they are but (as you ſaid) merry with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Be you merry with them good Madam, you know the ſerious worke I came about. In which
I ſodainly ſhall preſume to give you a re-viſite.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray do ſir Andrew, bring your Mad-man. My garden Lodgings ſhall be his bedlem. Come gentlemen tis Dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: We are your waiters Madam.

div.head: SCENE I.

lg.l: THeſe are the Lodgings, that my Lady appointed
For your diſtracted patient.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Like you 'em Doctor.

lg.l: Exceeding well. Excuſe me Gentlewoman
That now intreat your abſence.
Willingly. I am not taken with the ſight you bring:
For I ſee mad-folkes enough every day.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here ſet him downe. Unbind him, and unblind him.

div.stage: Ferdinand brought in a chaire bound and hooded, &c.

lg.l: Am I then taken priſoner in the North?
Wounded, diſarm'd and bound? I ſhall be ranſom'd
To which of your rebelliouſly uſurp'd
Caſtles ha' you brought me? you ſir Presbiter,
That better can pugnare then orare,
And ſo abjure all duty and allegiance—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Hee takes you for a Northerne Paſtor Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No matter what, let him run out his fancy.

lg.l: You were beſt to uſe me well; and like a ſouldier
Order will elſe be tane (though you know none.)

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You ſhall have all beſt uſage ſir.

lg.l: And uſe my horſe well too, and let my horſe and armor
Be decently preſerv'd and ſeene forth-comming
At my redemption.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: With all beſt care ſir.

lg.l: For I ſhall ſoone be ſent for, or fetch'd off
With ruine of your countrey 'bout your eares.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You ſhall have all content the countrey yeilds ſir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I ſhall have Oat-bread, Ale, and Bag-pipes, ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you'l be merry ſir.

lg.l: Merry! why not? come let's ha' cards; and you and I to cribbidge
For an od hundred pound, I meane not Scotch,
But ſterling Engliſh pieces, where's your money?
All gone in Ammunition, and charge Military.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'le finde you money enough.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O here's a third man, let's then to Gleeke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Crown Gleeke ſir, if you pleaſe.

lg.l: Crown Gleeke! no more?
You ſeeme to be a thrifty Covenanter
To play but at crowne Gleeke, whole piece Gleeke or nothing.
High as you pleaſe ſir, wee'l find money enough,
And pay us but our buyings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt ba●e mee Aces. You will play Tib and Tom.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All i' the Cards ſir.

lg.l: Away with cards. Bring dice, ſet all at hazard,
And though I loſe all, I have yet a project
That at the end o'th' war, and the great ſitting
Shall fetch all in agen. But O my Muſe!
How dare I ſo neglect thy inſpirations?
Give me Pen, Inke and Paper.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All's ready.

lg.l: Now will I write, nor will I emulate
Ovids ſmoth vaine, or Petraks buskind ſtile.
Nor Laura, nor Corinna did deſerve
To have their prayers written ●n ſuch Verſe
As i'le beſtow on her that I adore.
Liſten to me you bleſt Intelligences,
And, Phebus, ſtay thy courſe to heare me ſing
Her prayſes, for whoſe love th'inamor'd Gods
Would leave their proper ſeates, and in ſtoine ſhapes,
Converſe with mortalls, your ſoule-raviſhing ſpheres
Send forth your ſweeteſt harmony whilſt I ſing—
But O ſhee is diſdainfull; and her ſcorne
Hath blotted all the glory of her praiſe,
Away, away with all.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now ſir, doe you obſerve the roote of his Diſeaſe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I gueſſe at it, know you the remedy?

lg.l: Diſeaſe! what's that? who is diſeas'd? who wants a Remedy?
Are you ſir a Phiſitian?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This Gentleman is, and brings you remedy, be you patient.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O you will move him.

lg.l: You are a brace of Quacks,
That tie your knowledge unto dayes and houres
Mark'd out for good or ill i'th' Almanack.
Your beſt Receipts are candy for a cold;
And Carduns Benedictus for an ague,
Could you give life as Aeſculapius
Did to unjuſtly ſlaine Hippolitus,
You could preſcribe no remedy for me.
Goe ſtudy Gallen, and Hippocrates,
And when your rare ſimplicities have found
Simples to cure the Lunacy of Love,
Compoſe a potion, and adminiſter't
Unto the Family at Amſterdam.
I'le Phiſick you to morrow and allay
The heate of this ſtrong fit, or Leach it out.
I have venter'd to this houſe againe, aſſur'd
That now the humerous Lady is from home
Forgetting not her Love-trick put upon me
Which ſhe already boaſts to my diſgrace
For which I may require her Ladyſhip,
How dos your patient? a ſleepe! That's well.
No hee's but ſilent ſir, and it is well
That he is ſo, ſo long.
The Lords in honorable regard unto
His health directed me to viſite him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Do you not know me ſir?

lg.l: You are (I tak't) the Ghoſt of Dioniſius
The great tirannicall Court-ſchole-maſter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Your Friends at Court commend them to you Sir.

lg.l: What hither, unto hell? Extend their loves
So far, to finde me out? Pray let 'em know
That here's a trobled world in want of Stateſmen.
But tell the youthes and beauties there, they never
Shall finde a happier opportunity
To raiſe a new Plantation. They'l drive all
Before 'em here. For pride is at a ſtand;
Faſhions are all worne out, and no invention
For new here to be found: all beauty's loſt;
Nor have the greateſt Ladies here the act
To make ſo much as their poore Chamberm●yds:
Let 'em come downe, as many of the Gallants
As are made weary of their Wives or Miſtreſſes;
And, of thoſe Wives and Miſtreſſes, as many
As can their husbands, or their ſervants ſpare:
And what a yeare of Holy-dayes, a Jubile
Shall we have in hell then? Ha' old Lad!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What a wilde fancie's this!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Croſſe it not good ſir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pray give mee leave to touch it though, a little.

lg.l: But above all, finde out the Lady Strangelove
That humorous Madam, and tell her from me,
The many Lovers ſhee has ſent before her
Into theſe ſhades (where we can find no torments
Like thoſe that ſhee inflicted) have prevail'd
With the great Queene Proſerpina, that ſhee
Shall be in place next to her royall perſon.
The Lady Strangelove! you are in her houſe ſir,
Where doe you thinke you are? or who you are?
Pray call your ſelfe to mind ſir, are not you
The noble Cavalier and hopefull Courtier
The moſt accompliſh'd Knight ſir Ferdinando?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Forbeare ſir, you will move him ſtrongly elſe.

lg.l: I have authority for what I do ſir,
Can you forget your ſelfe ſir, or neglect
The bounteous fortunes, that the Court and Kingdome
Have in ſtore for you, both for paſt Atchievments,
And for the large endowments of court-vertue
Are found ſtill growing in you, ſtudied and practis'd
So to the life, as if you were built up
Vertues own Manſion, on her foure firme pillars?—
I hope he cannot flatter him into's wits
When 'tis the way to foole men out of 'em.
The Wiſdome, Juſtice, Magnanimity,
And temperance of court you are exactly
Fram'd and compos'd of, and indued with all
The excelencies that may adorne a man
By Nature, Fortune, Art and Induſtry!
And all this glorious light to be eclips'd;
And ſuch Divine perfections ſeeme to ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Pray ſir your eare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, moſt attentively.

lg.l: What do you thinke of Salsbury ſteeple ſir,
For a fit hunting ſpeare t' incounter with
The whore of Babilion? might I not firke her thinke you?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Your Doctrine dos not edify ſir Raphael.

lg.l: Is Oratour Demoſtines growne dumbe
O'th' ſodaine? what! no anſwer? give me a Knife
He is but tongue-tied.

sp.speaker: Ra:
sp.p: Guard me Divinity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I told you what you would doe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Patience good ſir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Patience in tortures?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Helpe here ſodainly!

lg.l: Do you ſally forth in troupes? Have I no troupe?
Give me my horſe and armes, and come a hundred.
Wee'l arme and horſe you, ſince y'are ſo unruly,
Away with him into his Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O doe you make me then your Knight o'th' ſhir● A tun o' Wine for that. Shoulder your Knight, advance your Knight, beare him out.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A Ferdinand, a Ferdinand, &c.

lg.l: This now to me is Muſick, Golden chimes
That rings all in with an aſſur'd advantage,
How now Sir Raphael! Frighted?
In all my diſputations all my travailes,
And all conſpiracies that have bin had
Aagainſt me, never met I an incounter
By man, or ſpirit that I feard ſo much,
Yet here's another fury.
By what oppreſſion or tiranny (for Law
I'm ſure could never do't) is my houſe here
Confiſcated or uſurp'd, and I become your ſlave?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Your ſlave, lay your commands on mee, what drudgery doe you appoint me to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Shee's mad too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Did not your Ladyſhip give way?

lg.l: To make my houſe a hell?
The noyſe of Bedlem is ſoft Muſick to 't.
Could your Projectorſhip find no houſe elſe
To make a mad-man madder in but mine?
And me as mad as he too with the trouble.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I was no principle in't good Madam.

lg.l: Was it your plot then ſir Philoſophaſter,
That ſo you might under pretext of reading
Philoſophy to him, to cure his madneſſe
Make your adreſſe to me to proſequte
Your Love-ſuite when I thought I had anſwer'd you,
But if you muſt proceede, o'recome me if you can,
Yet let me warne you to take heede withall
You pull not a diſeaſe unto you, that may
By your ungovern'd haſt poſt into
Your grave: for I ſhall prove a torment to you,
Though you'l take no denyall, take yet a warning.
I take it to forſake your houſe; and never
More to reſort where madneſſe raignes. Did I
Make love to you?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pardon mee vertuous ſir, it is my love to you that tortures mee into this wild diſtraction. O ſir Raphael.

lg.l: Now vertue guide me. I will ſhun this place
More then I would the Spaniſh Inquiſition.
I ſhall in time be rid of all ſuch Gueſts,
And have the liberty of mine owne houſe
With mine own company, and to mine own ends
Where are you Phil? I were but dead if I had not this
wench to foole withall ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I muſt be a little ſerious with you, ſhut the dore.

lg.l: Now am I call'd into correction,
When ſhee is vext and wants the company
Shee likes, then come I into queſtion,
'Tis common among Ladies with their women.
Why that down looke, as if you meant to fetch
An anſwer, or excuſe out of your Apron-ſtrings
Before you are charged or queſtion'd? what new faul●
Has paſt of late?
Doe you read any Madam
Upon my face or lookes? I never was in love
Much with my face, nor ever hated it. But if I thought
It had upon't, or in it, any treſpaſſe
Againſt your Ladyſhip (my heart being cleare)
Theſe Nayles ſhould claw it out.
Nay be not paſſionate Phil. I know you cannot
Forget the care I have had of you; nor ſhould you
Diſtruſt me in the promiſes I have made you,
Bearing your ſelfe according to your covenant Phil,
Of which one Article is to laugh with me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Go, you are ſuch a Lady, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now thou comſt to me wench: hadſt forgot?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You ſaid you would be ſerious.

lg.l: Doſt not thou know my ſeriouſneſſe is to laugh in private,
And that thou art bound to ſtir that humour in me?
There's but two things more condition'd in thy ſervice;
To do what I bid thee, and tell me the truth
In all things that I aske thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I Madam, you had never known that ſame elſe▪

lg.l: Of the clap thou hadſt i'the Countrey e're I took thee,
But haſt thou faithfully kept thine own e're ſince?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes moſt ſeverely Madam on your promiſe—

lg.l: Well we will have a husband then to ſolder up the old crack,
I have already made my choyce for you:
Your ſweete-heart Cit-wit makes moſt ſuite to you,
And has a good Eſtate, and wit enough
Too for a husband, and a handſome perſon.
I finde no fault in all that. But he is
So baſe a coward, that he may be ſoone
Beaten out of his wit and money.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if he ſhould prove valiant!

lg.l: If he were valiant now I could ſay ſomething,
But to wait for growing to't were ſuch a loſſe of time.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What ſay to Swayn-wit?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hee's the others extreame. I might feare him but never love him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What think you of my ſpeciall favorite Mr. Court|wit?

lg.l: As of a Courtier Madam, that has taſted
So much of all waters, that when he has a fountaine of his owne
Hee'l be too jealous of it.
And feard that every man will drink of's cup
When perhaps none dares touch it, were I it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What ſay to Dainty then the curious Limner?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I am bound from lying. Madam hee's the man.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well i'le take thy cauſe in hand wench: But yet we are not merry. I am inclin'd moſt jovially to mirth me thinks. Pray Jove ſome good be towards. Laugh or i'le pinch you, till you doe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha. O the picture drawer! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I, come, the Picture drawer.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
O, I love drawing and painting, as no Lady bet|ter,
who for the moſt part are of their occupation that profeſſe it. And ſhall I tell all Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: By all meanes Phil.—now ſhee's enter'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hope I am handſome enough too. For I have heard that Limners or Picture-drawers, doe covet to have th● faireſt and beſt featur'd wives, (or if not wives, Miſtreſſes) that they can poſſibly purchace, to draw naked Pictures by, as of Diana, Venus, Andromeda, Leda, or the like, either vertuous or laſcivious; whom they make to ſit or ſtand naked in all the ſeverall poſtures, and to lie as many wayes to helpe their art in drawing, who knowes how I may ſet his fancy a worke? and with mo|deſty enough. We were all naked once, and muſt be ſo againe. I could ſit for the naked Shepherdeſſe, with one Leg over the tother Knee, picking the Thorne out of her Foote moſt neatly, to make the Satyre peepe under.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well thou ſhalt have him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Miſtris Philomel.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let in the Boy. Now ſir your newes?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The mad Knights Doctor Madam intreats to ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now ſeekes he may aſſiſtance in his cure.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And Mr. Court wit, and the other Gentlemen are below.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Goe you and entertaine the Gentlemen, while I conſult with the Doctor, let him enter.

Now Mr. Doctor! you come to aske my counſell I know for your impatient Patient. But let me tell you firſt, the moſt learned Authors, that I can turne over; as Dioſcorides, Avicen, Galen, and Hyppocrates are much diſcrepant in their opinions concerning the remedies for his diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Therefore I truſt you'l pardon my weakneſſe, if my opinion jumps not altogether with your judgement.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Madam, my purpoſe was not—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: My purpoſe is to adviſe you though, that, if his Frenzie proceed from love as you conjecture, that you adminiſter of the rootes of Hellebore, deſtill'd together with Salt peter, and the flowers of blind Netles, I'le give you the proportions, and the quantity is to take.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Miſtake not me good Madam—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if his Malady grow out of ambition, and his over weening hopes of greatneſſe (as I conjecture) then he may take a top of Cedar, or an Oake-apple is very ſoveraigne with the ſpirit of Hempſeed.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Madam, I ſeeke no counſell in this caſe, my cun|ning is—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: To let me know, that that part of my houſe which I allow you is too little for you.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Shee's ſurely mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But you muſt claime poſſeſſion of the reſt, You are come to warne me out on't; are you not?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Miſtake not ſo good Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Or do you call my attendance on his perſon, by way of a Nurſe-keeper? I can do little ſervice.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: For my part Madam I am ſorry we are made the trouble of your houſe, and rather wiſh me out on't then your favour. But if your Ladyſhip will bee pleas'd to entertaine with patience the little I have to ſay.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Come to it quickly then.

lg.l: Firſt, let me tell you Madam, as 'tis manifeſt
You were the cauſe of his diſtraction,
Y'are bound in charity to yeild ſuch meanes
(With ſafety of your honor and eſtate)
As you may render for his reſtoration
VVhich of all the earthly meanes depends on you
If I know any thing in my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come to the point, you'ld have me viſit him.

lg.l: True Madam: for a ſight of you, ſhall more
Allure his reaſon to him, then all medicine
Can be preſcrib'd.
By your favour ſir, you ſay
Saving my honor and eſtate I am bound,
But may I with the ſafety of my Life,
And limbes and a whole skin dare venture.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: My life o' that.

lg.l: You might more ſafely lay
Lives of a hundred Patients.
Now hee's calme,
Now ſhall he ſee you, but at moſt ſecure
And modeſt diſtance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come for once i'le truſt you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Come out into the Garden here; and let them talke within, I ſay he ſhall talke with her; and his belly full, and doe with her too, her belly full, for all thou: an honeſt diſcreet Gentleman, and thou a coward and a cockſcombe. Beſides he has an art and quality to live upon, and maintaine her Lady-like, when all thy money may be gone. And yet thou prat'ſt o'thy two thouſand pound at uſe, when thou and thy money too are but an aſſe and's load tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well, you may ſpeake your pleaſure. This is no cauſe to fight for.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le make thee fight, or promiſe to fight with me, or ſomebody elſe before we part, or cut thee into pieces.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But tell me ſeriouſly doſt thou love my Ladies woman ſo well as to marry her, and ſuffer the Picture|drawer now to court her privately, and perhaps to draw and carry her from thee?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why he here will have it ſo you ſee, and pull'd mee out.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: It is to doe a cure upon thee, coward.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Coward! piſh! a common Name to men in buffe and feather. I ſcorne to anſwer to't.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why doſt thou weare a Sword? only to hurt mens feet that kick thee?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay you are too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace. I'le jowle your heads to|gether, and ſo beat ton with tother elſe. Why doſt thou were a Sword I ſay?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: To fight when I ſee cauſe.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Now he ſayes ſomething, yet, and may be curable.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What is a cauſe to fight for?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am not to tell you that ſir, It muſt be found out and given me before I ought to take notice.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You may ſafely ſay for Religion, King or Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darſt thou fight for Religion? ſay.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Who that has any Religion will fight I ſay?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I ſay thou haſt none. Speake, haſt thou any?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Truly, in this wavering world I know not how to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: La you. Hee'l ſay he has no King neither, rather then fight.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Why if he will not fight for him he is no Subject, and no Subject no King.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thanke you ſir, I would ha' ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: O thou wouldſt make a ſpeciall Souldier now!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, all are not choyce doggs that run, ſome are taken in to make up the cry.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And for thy Countrey, I dare ſweare thou wouldſt rather run it then fight for't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Run my Countrey I cannot, for I was borne i'the City. I am no clown to run my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darſt thou tell me of clowns thou cockney chick|en-hearted whelp thou?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Forbeare good ſir, there are countrey Gentlemen as well as clownes, and for the rank I honour you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Sirrah you lie, ſtrike me for that now; or I will beat thee abhominably.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Up to him man: wilt thou ſuffer all?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would—but—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You lie I ſay againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thinke I doe, I thinke I doe, and why ſhould I maintaine an evill cauſe?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The wench thou lov'ſt and doateſt on is a whore.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, if ſhe be 'tis not my fault, nor hers: ſomebody elſe made her ſo then I warrant you. But ſhould another man tell me ſo!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would ſay as much to him as to you. Nor in|deed is any mans report of that a ſufficient cauſe to pro|voke mee unleſſe ſhee her ſelfe confeſſ'd it, and then it were no cauſe at all.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a true City wit now.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I ſhould have wit ſir, and am acounted a wit within the walls. I am ſure my Father was Maſter of his company, and of the wiſeſt company too i'the city.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What company's that?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The Salters ſir. For ſal ſapit omnia you know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Your Father was a cuckold tho', and you the Son of a whore.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fight now or you'l die infamous, was your Mo|ther a whore?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Deny't and darſt, ſay, was ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively ſhee might be in reſpect of ſome holy woman, the Lady Ramſey, Miſtris Katherine Stubbs and ſuch, ha, ha. Is that a cauſe?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What! not to ſay your Mother was a whore?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He may ſay his pleaſure, It hurts her not: ſhee is dead and gone. Beſides, at the beſt ſhee was but a wo|man, and at the worſt ſhee might have her frailtie● like other women. And is that a cauſe for mee to fight for the dead, when wee are forbidden to pray for 'em?

sp.speaker: Cou
sp.p: But were your Mother living now, what would you ſay or doe?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why, I would civilly ask her if ſhe were a whore? If ſhe confeſs'd it, then he were in the right, and I ought not to fight againſt him: for my cauſe were naught. If ſhe deny'd it, then he were in an error, and his cauſe were naught, and I would not fight, 'twere better he ſhould live to repent his errour.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Nay, now if I do not kill thee let me be hang'd for idleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hold I am unprepar'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I care not—unleſſe thou ſweare preſently, and without all equivocation upon this ſword—

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Scabberd and all I pray ſir, The cover of the book is allowd in courts to ſweare upon.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Well ſir, now you ſhall ſweare to challenge the next that wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, if the wrong give me ſufficient cauſe.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Cauſe agen! ſuppoſe that fellow within ſhould take your wench from you? which very likely he has done already: for I left 'em cloſe on a couch together Kiſſing and—

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Gi' me the booke, i'le have her from him, or him from her if he be without her belly, or Kill him if he be within her.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tis well a cauſe may be found at laſt tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I like a man, whom neither Lie, Kick, Battoune, ſcandall, Friends, or Parents, the wrongs of Countrey, King or Religion can move, that will, yet, fight for his
wench. Thou wilt be one of the ſtiffe blades o' the time I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A wench is a moving cauſe:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, here helpe—ha—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why doſt not draw and run in upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: After you I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A pox upon thee art thou down agen?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No ſir, I am drawn you ſee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Help, help, a rape, a rape, murder, help!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Cou. Tis time to fly then.

div.stage: Enter Dainty (his ſword drawne) and Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I come my Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What's the matter Phil?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What cry was that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Was it not you that caus'd it ſir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Was it not here?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Was it not you that cry'd?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Is there helpe, helpe, helpe?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O tis my Lady in the Madmans chamber. Is her mirth come to this?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Where, which way?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Here, here the dore's made faſt.

div.stage: Exe. omnes Pret. Cit. his ſword drawn. Doctor looks out above. Floriſh his ſword.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le breake it open.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Help here, help the Lady; help the Lady.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We are a comming, you ſhall have help enough
I warrant, what's the matter? you ſhall not lack for help—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away Meduſa. Hence, thou haſt transformd me. Stone, ſtone, I am all ſtone. Bring morter and make a bul-wark of me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O that's the Mad-man! How madly he talkes!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
Stones to make a bul-warke quoth a! If he had
but to make a brace of Demy-culvering bullets, they were thumpers I thinke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down, but reare me up, and make me my own ſtatue.

div.stage: Enter Strangelove, Swain-wit, Court-wit, Dainty. Phil.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch a practice?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: A meere accident of madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I ſay it was a practiſe in the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yet he calld out for help.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You had broke up the dore firſt. That was but to colour his trechery.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A new way, and a very learned one I promiſe you; to cure madneſſe with a plaiſter of warme Lady|gutts.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He would ha' had a mad bout with my Lady it ſeemes. He would ha' vented his madnes into her. And ſhe could ha' drawn better then the Leaches.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: If you believe this Madam, tho' ſir Ferdinand be by his madneſſe excuſable in the attempt, you ought to be reveng'd upon the Doctor.
